016
017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.hsluv;
018
019import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.Interpolations;
020import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.Interpolations.InterpolationFunction;
021import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.MathTools;
022import com.github.tommyettinger.ds.FloatList;
023
024/**
025 * Static methods for handling gradients of smoothly-changing colors, typically inside of {@link FloatList}s.
026 * The intent is for the FloatArray to be used as a sequence of packed float HSLuv colors. You can create a new
027 * FloatArray gradient with {@link #makeGradient(float, float, int, InterpolationFunction)}, but any FloatArray will work
028 * (although it only makes sense if it contains packed float colors or is empty). Once you have a FloatArray, you can
029 * pass it to {@link #appendGradient(FloatList, float, float, int, InterpolationFunction)} to make a gradient between two
030 * colors, or {@link #appendGradientChain(FloatList, int, InterpolationFunction, float...)} to make a gradient between more
031 * than two colors. You can also customize each section between colors with
032 * {@link #appendPartialGradient(FloatList, float, float, int, InterpolationFunction)}, which is just like appendGradient() but
033 * doesn't add the end color (since it is the start color of the next partial gradient, until you finally end by
034 * appending just the end). Using appendPartialGradient(), you can have each transition use a different number of steps.
035 * <br>
036 * This class does some special handling for HSLuv colors.
037 */
038public class GradientTools {
039    /**
040     * No need to instantiate.
041     */
042    private GradientTools(){
043    }
044
045    /**
046     * Creates a FloatList gradient from the packed float HSLuv color {@code start} to the packed float HSLuv color
047     * {@code end}, taking the specified number of steps and using linear interpolation.
048     * @param start the packed float HSLuv color to start with
049     * @param end the packed float HSLuv color to end on
050     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2, and must be non-negative
051     * @return a new FloatList that contains the requested gradient
052     */
053    public static FloatList makeGradient(float start, float end, int steps) {
054        return makeGradient(start, end, steps, Interpolations.linear);
055    }
056    /**
057     * Creates a FloatList gradient from the packed float HSLuv color {@code start} to the packed float HSLuv color
058     * {@code end}, taking the specified number of steps and using the specified InterpolationFunction for how it transitions.
059     * @param start the packed float HSLuv color to start with
060     * @param end the packed float HSLuv color to end on
061     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2, and must be non-negative
062     * @param interpolation a libGDX InterpolationFunction that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
063     * @return a new FloatList that contains the requested gradient
064     */
065    public static FloatList makeGradient(float start, float end, int steps, InterpolationFunction interpolation) {
066        FloatList appending = new FloatList(steps);
067        if(steps <= 0) {
068            return appending;
069        }
070        if(steps == 1) {
071            appending.add(start);
072            return appending;
073        }
074        appendPartialGradient(appending, start, end, steps - 1, interpolation).add(end);
075        return appending;
076    }
077
078    /**
079     * Appends a gradient from the packed float HSLuv color {@code start} to the packed float HSLuv color {@code end},
080     * taking the specified number of steps and using linear InterpolationFunction for how it transitions.
081     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
082     * @param start the packed float HSLuv color to start with
083     * @param end the packed float HSLuv color to end on
084     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
085     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
086     */
087    public static FloatList appendGradient(FloatList appending, float start, float end, int steps) {
088        return appendGradient(appending, start, end, steps, Interpolations.linear);
089    }
090    /**
091     * Appends a gradient from the packed float HSLuv color {@code start} to the packed float HSLuv color {@code end},
092     * taking the specified number of steps and using the specified InterpolationFunction for how it transitions.
093     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
094     * @param start the packed float HSLuv color to start with
095     * @param end the packed float HSLuv color to end on
096     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
097     * @param interpolation a libGDX InterpolationFunction that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
098     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
099     */
100    public static FloatList appendGradient(FloatList appending, float start, float end, int steps, InterpolationFunction interpolation) {
101        if(appending == null)
102            return null;
103        if(steps <= 0) {
104            return appending;
105        }
106        if(steps == 1) {
107            appending.add(start);
108            return appending;
109        }
110        appending.ensureCapacity(steps);
111        appendPartialGradient(appending, start, end, steps - 1, interpolation).add(end);
112        return appending;
113    }
114
115    /**
116     * Appends a gradient between several packed float HSLuv colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses linear
117     * InterpolationFunction for the whole gradient. Appends to the end of {@code appending} and produces a total of
118     * {@code steps} colors.
119     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
120     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
121     * @param chain an array or varargs of packed float HSLuv colors that this will interpolate through in order
122     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
123     */
124    public static FloatList appendGradientChain(FloatList appending, int steps, float... chain) {
125        return appendGradientChain(appending, steps, Interpolations.linear, chain);
126    }
127
128    /**
129     * Appends a gradient between several packed float HSLuv colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses linear
130     * InterpolationFunction for the whole gradient. Appends to the end of {@code appending} and produces a total of
131     * {@code steps} colors.
132     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
133     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
134     * @param chain a FloatList of packed float HSLuv colors that this will interpolate through in order
135     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
136     */
137    public static FloatList appendGradientChain(FloatList appending, int steps, FloatList chain) {
138        return appendGradientChain(appending, steps, Interpolations.linear, chain);
139    }
140
141    /**
142     * Appends a gradient between several packed float HSLuv colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses the specified
143     * InterpolationFunction for the whole gradient, which can make some colors use smaller sections than others. Appends to the
144     * end of {@code appending} and produces a total of {@code steps} colors.
145     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
146     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
147     * @param interpolation a libGDX InterpolationFunction that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
148     * @param chain a FloatList of packed float HSLuv colors that this will interpolate through in order
149     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
150     */
151    public static FloatList appendGradientChain(FloatList appending, int steps, InterpolationFunction interpolation, FloatList chain) {
152        if (appending == null)
153            return null;
154        if(chain == null)
155            return appending;
156        if (steps <= 0 || chain.size() == 0) {
157            return appending;
158        }
159        if (steps == 1 || chain.size() == 1) {
160            appending.add(chain.first());
161            return appending;
162        }
163        appending.ensureCapacity(steps);
164        int limit = steps - 1, splits = chain.size() - 1;
165        float step = 1f / steps, change = 0f;
166        for (int i = 0; i < limit; i++) {
167            float interp = interpolation.apply(change);
168            float splint = Math.min(Math.max(interp * splits, 0f), splits - 0.000001f);
169            int idx = (int)splint;
170            appending.add(ColorTools.lerpFloatColors(chain.get(idx), chain.get(idx+1), MathTools.norm(idx, idx +1, splint)));
171            change += step;
172        }
173        appending.add(chain.get(splits));
174        return appending;
175    }
176
177    /**
178     * Appends a gradient between several packed float HSLuv colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses the specified
179     * InterpolationFunction for the whole gradient, which can make some colors use smaller sections than others. Appends to the
180     * end of {@code appending} and produces a total of {@code steps} colors.
181     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
182     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
183     * @param interpolation a libGDX InterpolationFunction that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
184     * @param chain an array or varargs of packed float HSLuv colors that this will interpolate through in order
185     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
186     */
187    public static FloatList appendGradientChain(FloatList appending, int steps, InterpolationFunction interpolation, float... chain) {
188        if (appending == null)
189            return null;
190        if(chain == null)
191            return appending;
192        if (steps <= 0 || chain.length == 0) {
193            return appending;
194        }
195        if (steps == 1 || chain.length == 1) {
196            appending.add(chain[0]);
197            return appending;
198        }
199        appending.ensureCapacity(steps);
200        int limit = steps - 1, splits = chain.length - 1;
201        float step = 1f / steps, change = 0f;
202        for (int i = 0; i < limit; i++) {
203            float interp = interpolation.apply(change);
204            float splint = Math.min(Math.max(interp * splits, 0f), splits - 0.000001f);
205            int idx = (int)splint;
206            appending.add(ColorTools.lerpFloatColors(chain[idx], chain[idx+1], MathTools.norm(idx, idx +1, splint)));
207            change += step;
208        }
209        appending.add(chain[splits]);
210        return appending;
211    }
212
213    /**
214     * Exactly like {@link #appendGradient(FloatList, float, float, int)}, but does not include
215     * {@code end} in what it appends to {@code appending}. This is intended for the implementation of chained
216     * gradients, where the end of a previous gradient becomes the start of the next one. This still uses the specified
217     * number of steps, it just doesn't append {@code end} in the last step.
218     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
219     * @param start the packed float HSLuv color to start with
220     * @param end the packed float HSLuv color to end just before
221     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
222     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to its end
223     */
224    public static FloatList appendPartialGradient(FloatList appending, float start, float end, int steps) {
225        return appendPartialGradient(appending, start, end, steps, Interpolations.linear);
226    }
227    /**
228     * Exactly like {@link #appendGradient(FloatList, float, float, int, InterpolationFunction)}, but does not include
229     * {@code end} in what it appends to {@code appending}. This is intended for the implementation of chained
230     * gradients, where the end of a previous gradient becomes the start of the next one. This still uses the specified
231     * number of steps, it just doesn't append {@code end} in the last step.
232     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
233     * @param start the packed float HSLuv color to start with
234     * @param end the packed float HSLuv color to end just before
235     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
236     * @param interpolation a libGDX InterpolationFunction that can be used to customize how start transitions toward end
237     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to its end
238     */
239    public static FloatList appendPartialGradient(FloatList appending, float start, float end, int steps, InterpolationFunction interpolation){
240        if(appending == null)
241            return null;
242        if(steps <= 0) {
243            return appending;
244        }
245        if(steps == 1) {
246            appending.add(start);
247            return appending;
248        }
249        int limit = steps;
250        float step = 1f / steps, change = 0f;
251        for (int i = 0; i < limit; i++) {
252            appending.add(ColorTools.lerpFloatColors(start, end, interpolation.apply(change)));
253            change += step;
254        }
255        return appending;
256    }
257}
